DOCUMENT 438
ELECTRONICALLY FILED
1/8/2026 9:24 AM
70-DR-2023-900051.01
CIRCUIT COURT OF
TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
PATRICK CRADDOCK, CLERK
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR,
Respondent,
v. CASE NO.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND,
Petitioner.
MOTION FOR CONTEMPT
COMES NOW, Petitioner BRITTANY GILLILAND, by and through the undersigned
counsel of record, Barbara H. Agricola, with the law firm of Agricola Law, LLC, and files this
Motion for Contempt. In support thereof, Petitioner states as follows:
1. On November 6, 2025, This Honorable Court ordered Father to comply with the
Parties’ holiday visitation schedule as set out in the Parties’ Divorce Settlement
Agreement [Doc. 416];
2. On November 6, 2025, Father filed a Motion to Set Aside Order Granting Holiday
Visitation as an attempt to deprive Mother of her parental right to see her own child
[Doc. 422];
3. On November 12, 2025 this Honorable Court issued an Order denying Father’s motion
[Doc. 429]. The Order states, in part:
It is well established law that both a parent and a child have a fundamental right to free
association, care, and control with each other, provided the parent is a fit parent, and
that right extends to reasonable rights of visitation for a non-custodial situation.
See November 12, 2025 Order ¶ 1.
4. This Honorable Court also restated that the evidence provided thus far does not
“provide a sufficient basis to deprive either parent of visitation” for this holiday season.
See Order [Doc. 429].
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Motion for Contempt
Page 1 of 6
DOCUMENT 438
5. Given the above circumstances, Mother should have been able to fully exercise her
visitation awarded to her in the Parties’ Final Order of Divorce. However, as seen by
Father’s prior history in blocking any and all visitation with the Minor Child A.K., it
should come as no surprise to this Court that Mother was unable to exercise her holiday
visitation;
6. On December 4, 2025, the undersigned’s office reached out to opposing counsel to
confirm the holiday visitation dates per the agreement. Opposing counsel stated,
“Blaine’s Christmas is from 12-18-2025 to Christmas Day (12-25) at 6:00, then
Brittany has 12-25 at 6:00 until 1-1-2026 at 6:00 for her Christmas, then her weekend
would be Jan 2, 3, 4,” which the undersigned then confirmed and relayed to Mother.
The undersigned corrected that the pick-up time for Mother on December 25, 2025 is
in fact 12:00pm, not 6:00pm which opposing counsel previously stated, which was
confirmed by the opposing counsel in order to avoid any potential miscommunication
between Mother and Father when the time to exchange the Minor Children came;
7. On December 21, 2025, the Parties met for their weekly family dinner. During this
dinner, Father explained that the Minor Child, A.K., had planned for an extracurricular
trip through her church from December 27, 2025 until January 6, 2026. This would
“coincidentally” conflict with Mother’s holiday visitation which was to begin on
December 25, 2025 and end on January 1, 2026. Since this was during Mother’s
visitation, she had arranged for A.K. to attend a family gathering before promptly
returning A.K. to Father’s home for her trip;
8. Following this dinner, Mother received a phone call from Father where he had only
mentioned the Minor Child, B.M., for holiday visitation;
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Motion for Contempt
Page 2 of 6
DOCUMENT 438
9. As a result, the undersigned reached out once more to the opposing counsel on Tuesday,
December 23, 2025 to confirm that Father will comply with this Court’s orders, no
response was received;
10. When the exchange of the Minor Children occurred on December 25, 2025, Father
asked if the pick-up time could be pushed back one hour so that Minor Child B.M.
could play with his Christmas present. Mother informed Father that she was already on
the road to pick up the Minor Children, to which Father then informed B.M. that Mother
refused to allow him to play with his toy, causing B.M. to be upset with Mother upon
Mother’s arrival. This was another manipulation tactic by Father to foster negative
emotions towards Mother and to change the Minor Child’s perception of Mother;
11. Furthermore, Father’s sister, Katie McGregor, was at Father’s residence helping the
Minor Child ,A.K., pack for her trip at the time of the visitation exchange. When
Mother asked if A.K. was coming with B.M. into the car for pick up, Father reportedly
stated “if you want to go you can go” to A.K., to which she declined and went back
inside Father’s residence;
12. This Court has been explicitly clear regarding visitation especially as it relates to
putting the responsibility of exercising visitation in the Minor Child A.K.’s hands.
Father has previously made and continues to make zero attempt to encourage visitation
between the Minor Child A.K. and Mother and consistently engages in parental
alienation;
13. On July 24, 2025, this Court issued an Order stating, in part, “Both parties are to parent
and not permit the/a child to control the operations of this Court’s orders.” See July 24,
2025 Order [Doc. 222];
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Motion for Contempt
Page 3 of 6
DOCUMENT 438
14. This Court also stated during the July 31, 2024 Show Cause Hearing that “I don’t mind
talking to her again and letting her know if she don’t do what I tell her she’s got to do,
then I may have to change custody.” See Transcript page 6, lines 16-18 [Doc. 138] and,
“A ten-year-old can’t tell us what we’re going to do,” See Transcript page 6, line 25
[Doc. 138];
15. This Court’s position has been made clear since the initiation of this action that the
Minor Child is not to dictate whether visitation is to be exercised. Father has continued
to blatantly disregard this Court’s orders and refuses to bear any responsibility for
ensuring that visitation is properly exercised. Father continues to place this burden onto
a minor and instills distaste towards A.K.’s own mother, creating a rift and severing
any familial bond that Mother attempts to create, which is the definition of parental
alienation. Indeed, Father has even successfully blocked the reunification therapy that
was ordered by the Court with no consequences;
16. After numerous instances of Father showing clear disregard for this Court’s authority
it is abundantly clear that Father should be held in contempt of this Court and be ordered
to pay attorney’s fees to Mother associated with all filings related to the Parties’ holiday
visitation. Mother also requests that make-up visitation time between the Minor Child
A.K. be ordered immediately as zero visitation between A.K. and Mother was exercised
due to Father’s noncompliance.
WHEREFORE, PREMISES CONSIDERED, Mother respectfully prays this Honorable
Court hold Father in contempt of this Court and ORDER attorney’s fees associated with
the filing of this motion and other related filings be paid by Father to Mother and ORDER
immediate make-up visitation with the Minor Child A.K. and Mother.
Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Motion for Contempt
Page 4 of 6
DOCUMENT 438
Respectfully submitted on January 8, 2026.
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola (AGR004)
Attorney for Petitioner
OF COUNSEL:
AGRICOLA LAW
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, Alabama 36801
Telephone: 334.759.7557

Motion for Contempt
